p: Similar to our results, 16 constituents were identified in commercial thyme oil in a study by Tak et al. [ 30], with thymol (50.2%) and p-cymene (33.1%) of the first and second most abundant compound, respectively. Gaire et al. found that p-cymene (29.5%) and thymol (22.7%) were the major components in commercial red thyme oil [ 31], but there were differences in minor components and the proportion of constituents. Carvacrol accounted for 2.5% of thyme oil in our study but was found as 0 and 1.4% in the study of Tak et al. [ 30] and Gaire et al. [ 31], respectively. Lemos et al. proved that the composition and proportion of thyme oil can be remarkably influenced by plant age, collecting seasons and storage time [ 32]. The variations in composition rate and minor constitutions mentioned above may be attributed to the diversity growing area, different growth time of the plants and different extraction methods used.
